thread.title: The North still backs Brexit one year after EU referendum - but we're pessimistic

author: Jonathan Walker
title: The North still backs Brexit one year after EU referendum - but we're pessimistic
text:
Get daily   
The North still backs Brexit but there is little confidence in the Government’s ability to negotiate a good deal with the European Union. 
One year after the EU referendum vote, a survey found that support for Brexit is higher in the North of England than in any other part of the UK. 
But a significant minority of people in the region fear it will lead to higher prices in the shops and fewer jobs. 
The survey, by polling company YouGov, found 48% of people in the North of England believe the UK was right to vote to leave the EU, with 39% saying it was wrong. 
This is a contrast with the national figure, as just 44% of people across the UK think the country made the right choice while 45% think Britain was wrong to vote to leave. European Council President Donald Tusk, right, poses for photographers with British Prime Minister Theresa May (Photo: Reuters Pool) 
Just 15% of people in the North think the UK should either just ignore the referendum result and stay in anyway, or hold a second vote so people have a chance to change their minds. 
Attitudes are different in some other parts of the country. In London, 32% said they wanted to remain in the EU or to hold another referendum, 
But while the North still backs Brexit, voters aren’t convinced the Government is going to get a good deal. 
Asked how well or badly the Government is doing at negotiating Britain’s exit from the European Union, 26% of people in the North said the Government is doing well - and 45% said it was doing badly. 
The survey found 29% of people in the North expect goods to become more expensive in the shops, and 21% said companies would be less likely to invest in the UK. 
And 14% of people in the North, around one in seven, expect quitting the EU to plunge the UK into a full-blown recession. The European Central Bank in Frankfurt, Germany (Photo: John Walton/PA Wire) 
But 31% of people in the region said Brexit would allow us to strike trade deals with other countries, while 27% said a positive impact would be a fall in immigration. 
Brexit talks have begin, a year after the EU referendum on June 23 2016. 
But EU leaders have said it’s not too late for the UK to change its mind. 
European Council president Donald Tusk indicated the door remains open for the UK to remain in the EU. He quoted John Lennon’s Imagine at a press conference in Brussels, saying “you may say I’m a dreamer, but I’m not the only one” while addressing the prospect of the UK remaining in the bloc. Read More How you could keep your rights as an EU citizen after Brexit 
Mr Tusk said: “The Brexit negotiations started three days ago. It is a most difficult process, for which the EU is well prepared. 
“You can hear different predictions coming from different people about the possible outcome of these negotiations - hard Brexit, soft Brexit or no deal. 
“Some of my British friends have even asked me whether Brexit could be reversed and whether I could imagine an outcome where the UK stays part of the EU. 
“I told them that, in fact, the European Union was built on dreams that seemed impossible to achieve. So, who knows. You may say I’m a dreamer, but I’m not the only one.” 
France’s new president Emmanuel Macron also restated his view that the UK could perform a U-turn on Brexit, and acknowledged the need to address the problems caused by free movement of people - one of the triggers for the Leave vote. 
He told the Guardian: “The door is open until the moment you walk through it. It’s not up to me to say it’s closed. 
“But from the moment things are engaged with a timescale and an objective, it’s very hard to go back, we can’t lie to ourselves.” 
The Queen’s Speech on Wednesday included the announcement of eight Brexit bills, which the Government will need to get approved over the next two years. 
It could be a challenge for Theresa May’s Government , as the Tories are eight seats shy of a Commons majority. Like us on Facebook
